Description: Small mould-made scarab in glazed composition; back simply modelled with incised single lines, representing the features of clypeus, prothorax and elytra; at side, legs not understood, represented by broad incised lines roughly forming a triangle, but not cut away; underside stamped or incised (?) with three hieroglyphic signs arranged vertically with Maat feather and ankh sign above neb-basket sign; longitudinally pierced; scant remains of turquoise glaze; pale yellowish cream core.
Curator's comments: Petrie's drawing does not indicate a neb-basket sign (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, no. 95). However, as the inscription is quite eroded, it was probably difficult to see. Though the hieroglyphic signs could have just some magical value, it seems more plausible that this is a cryptographic reading for the name of Amun-Ra (on the cryptic writing of the name of Amun: Drioton 1957). This scarab belongs to a type, widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93-107, type XXVIII B, subtype B90-96, see especially B90 for this piece; on the various productions of the "Scarab Factory", see also Webb forthcoming). Drioton, E. 1957, 'Trigrammes d'Amon', Festschrift Hermann Junker zum 80. Geburtstag (Wiener Zeitschrift für die Kunde des Morgenlandes 54), Wien, 11-33. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. Webb, V. forthcoming, Faience finds from Naukratis and their implications for the chronology of the site, in R. Thomas (ed.), forthcoming. Naukratis in Context I: The Nile Delta as a Landscape of Connectivity. Proceedings of the First Naukratis Project Workshop held at The British Museum 16th – 17th December 2011.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 95)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p.103-104, Type XXVIII B90)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.118) (phase 3)
